advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEB. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1985?)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Power 3000 released in the USA.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://hem.passagen.se/clab/adam/lambda/" target="_blank">Adam's Lambda 8300 page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #1 (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Apple II advert.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Clear the kitchen table. Bring in the color TV. Plug in your new Apple ll and connect any standard cassette recorder / player. Now, you're ready for an evening of discovery in the new world of personal computers.<br> Only Apple ll makes it that easy. At $1298, it includes video graphics in 15 colors, 8KB ROM and 4KB RAM... It's the first personal computer with a fast version of BASIC permanently stored in ROM...<br><br> Apple ll is also available in board-only form to the do-it-yourself hobbyist. Has all of the features of the Apple ll system but does not include case, keyboard, power supply or game paddles. $598</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://uratomo.hp.infoseek.co.jp/game/museum/msx/f1xd.htm" target="_blank">Dreaming Tomorrow</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> Z-2 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: Cromemco microcomputers are the fastest and most powerful available. They use the Z80 microprocessor which is widely regarded as the standard of the future. So you're in the technical fore with the Z-2</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Most small system users think all microcomputers are created aqual. And they're right. If you want performance, convenience, styling, high technology and reliability (and who doesn't?) your micro usually has a price tag that looks mote like a mini. It seems big performance always means big bucks. But not so with the SuperBrain...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN ADVERT (JUNE,1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert for MPF-III in June 1984 issue of Electronics Australia magazine.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert on the Peerless 150 terminal</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #2 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>More power for less money</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOFTCARD COPY</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert for one of the numerous copies of the Microsoft SotfCard. Initially, they were manufactured in the United States then in Asia. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Why paying more ?"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> F.D. UNIT ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>BBC floppy disc unit was delivered with a 8271 FD controller chip and a Filing System software in ROM to be fitted into the BBC system.<br> Two versions of F.D. units were available:<br> - A single drive unit, single side, single density, 100 KB space.<br> - A dual drive version, double side, double density, 800 KB space. <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8BS.com</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DICK SMITH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Price list close-up in Australian$:<br> Basic CAT computer X-7500 <b>$1195.00</b><br> Disk Drive X-7505 <b>$1495.00</b><br> Disk Controller X-7510 <b>$149.95</b><br> Emulator Cartridge X-7530 <b>$149.95</b><br> Dual Joysticks X-7520 <b>$49.95</b><br> RF Modulator X-7550 <b>$49.95</b><br> RS-232C Serial Adaptor X-7515 <b>$149.95</b><br> Printer Cable (Centronics) X-7540 <b>$844.95</b><br> Filer Utilities Disk with DOS & Manual X-7512 <b>$59.95</b><br> High resolution RVB monitor X-1193 <b>$995.00</b><br> RGB Cable X-7560 <b>$44.95</b><br> High Res. Green Monitor X-1220 <b>$395.00</b></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Micro Decision have been presented at the 1983 Hannover show.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.museo8bits.com" target="_blank">www.museo8bits.com</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, the Victor 9000 features was compared with those of four competitor computers: IBM PC, Xerox 820, Apple III and TRS-80 Model II. <br><br> Victor features was definitely higher than all of the desktop computers of the time, including the IBM PC. </blockquote>

computer.description:
The Robik was a russian ZX Spectrum clone. It was produced in the city of Czerkasy.
It had 64KB RAM (shared with 16KB ROM) and independed 8KB video RAM (as real speccy, by the way). The keyboard was quite good (apparently) and quite complete. It had even switches to choose between latin and russian character fonts.
A Kempston interface was built in, with separate keys to emulate joystick, which was very convenient in programs that was not games and use the Kempston interface to control the cursor.
Some other advantages: - CGA video output for professional monitors - Standard tape interface - TV RGB interface - Ability to invert colors to use with some "strange" TV's and monitors - Separate brightness regulators for R, G, B (bottom side) - One system expansion slot on motherboard. In most cases user had to modify left side of the keyboard (making special hole). Otherwise expansion cards couldn't fit inside :(
________
Source : ZX LAND 6.5 and Maxim from Russia
computer.keyboard: QWERTY full-stroke keyboard, 55 keys. EDIT, SHIFT (x 3), RESET, DEL, arrow keys
computer.name: Robik
computer.ports: RGB video output, Kempston joystick, Tape interface, Monitor video output
